instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Problem
threads.message: Hello. Got this one here, which I'm thinking may have a NAND problem. It does not turn on, don't negotiate 20V with charger, BUT, after taking some measurements and inspecting the board a little under the microscope I found that <SIGNAL>PP2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> is around 3.5V oscillating and UN100 gets a little warm. Charger stays at 5V and takes 0.42A from charger. Some caps around UN100 were bad and I replaced them, but still same symptom. If I take RN430 the board power cycles, going to 20V, trying to turn on and shuts off, cycling. I'm suspecting bad UN100, but who knows...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Problem
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> comes from L7760.
Check R770C and its traces (XW7760).
If good, then bad <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.

Just in case, check ohm resistance between L7760 and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> rail.
When RN430 is removed, what's <SIGNAL>2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Problem
threads.message: <SIGNAL>2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL> is 3.5Ëœ3,6V with or without RN430. Traces and R770C are good, bad <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>. No repair for this one then as I don't have any donor boards from this model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Problem
threads.message: PMUs from M1 14" and 16" are compatible.
